messageBody:
On 17 Apr 2007 23:26:31 -0700, Don Hill <justj2ee@...> wrote:
> Hi,
>
> remember one of the rules of Unit test, test in isolation,

Yes, and like all rules, it has exceptions. Besides, the original
poster was not necessarily talking about unit testing.

Time and again, I've had the need to create tests that depend on each
other. It's not very common (most of my tests are isolated), but when
you encounter this problem, you really need a way to specify that
certain tests depend on each other, for two reasons:

- You are testing logic that has dependencies itself, so it should
come as no surprise that the tests that exercise it need dependencies
as well.

- More accurate reporting. In the case where a test that failed
causes dozens of others to fail as well, would you rather read "1
SUCCESS, 19 FAILURES" or "1 SUCCESS, 1 FAILURE, 18 SKIPS"?

The latter error message singles out the test that really failed and
also tells you that for now, you can ignore the other 18 tests that
were skipped because they didn't really fail: they simply didn't run.

The fact that JUnit doesn't support dependent testing was one of the
reasons why I created TestNG in the first place, and David, I still
have some hope that at some point, JUnit is going to go beyond its
"unit testing" scope and start addressing other forms of testing as
well :-)
